title: Portable and Practical
body:
Size 02 is exactly the size for my usage: big enough to put over a small carafe to make coffee for two, small enough opening to go over my 3 c. thermos, still works to make a single cup in the afternoon or for dessert, and wide enough for my jumbo 18 oz workday morning cup. It is the happy medium.

This isn't my first pourover: my first is a reusable mesh, which took a little upkeep to keep the pores clear but was easy enough to clean out with a garbage disposal. But getting to clean it out was a pain on deployment, having to find somewhere to dump the grounds and so on and so on. I went to the bother of lugging a kettle with me all around the world, because I owned the electrical gear so even if the cooks couldn't heat water, I happened to be able to plug an electric kettle in. I switched to a camping french press, because that was easier to pack and move if it was still dirty. On my next deployment, one of the other guys brought his Hario, and then I saw him pitch the highly biodegradable paper and grounds, and I realized using the paper wasn't going to be the end of the Amazon rainforest.

This brews faster. It's more consistent. The plastic can get scratched, unlike the glass, but if it should ever break, I won't have glass all in my clothes. A lot of the world separates compost (including now parts of the US), so clean up is easy. Did you know roaches and ants don't like coffee grounds? Fringe benefits!

And you don't have to buy the Hario brand filters! Just buy the #4 cone from your favorite brand and fold the corner to make a sharp point. Make sure, if you fold it near the crimp, that you don't rip a hole by mistake, and boom, you're in business. If you leave it flattened, it will rip. With folding, I've had a few grounds all of twice in the last few years, between the other guy's Hario and when I bought this one.

Love this product! It's the only thing I use now.

title: Great clarity of flavour; difficult to use; ultimately rewarding
body:
I'm nowhere near an expert on pourovers or even coffee in general, but I can recognize a good cup when I taste one. The v60 enables me to really focus in on the clearer, "higher" notes in the beans I'm brewing. I haven't used anything better than "nice supermarket" beans but I use a good-quality, consistent grinder (the Timemore C1) and grind fresh immediately before brewing. Yes, you need a very consistent grinder; if you have one that produces a lot of fines go with something more forgiving like a Kalita Wave or a Melitta cup.

When brewing with the v60 it's recommended you choose a bean with a lot of "high", clear notes; fruity beans work best, and I'd avoid anything too dark, chocolatey or roasty. Coffee a week or so past a fresh roast is ideal; not only will that help you dial in the particulars of the v60 a lot easier, you'll enjoy it a lot more too. You can use a few different methods to make a great cup (I suggest Scott Rao's) but you have to adhere very strictly to those methods or you're gonna have a bad time. This brewer is finicky and requires you to be rather precise with how you prepare coffee in it. However, a lot of people say the v60 allows for amazing clarity, but less body, than most other methods.

All in all, despite the difficulty in use this is a great dripper that I'd recommend to an enthusiast or someone with a consistent grinder who wants to ramp up their coffee game.

title: Simple and effective
body:
I would recommend combining this with an electric kettle, if you don't already own one. I found one on sale at Target for $12, and these two pieces, combined, are the best $20 coffee maker you can buy. (I still use this setup many days when I don't want to bother with the $800 espresso machine my husband bought us for Christmas.)

You can watch a lot of videos about the proper way to make pour over coffee. You should probably watch one or two. I don't think it's necessary to stress about all the details. Most of the importance is being a little bit slow about everything. One thing I took away from the videos I watched is that the first pour of water on the grounds should be just enough to get them all wet. Something about "opening them up." Imagine loose leaf tea leaves opening up in hot water, except you can't really see it, because coffee grounds are too small. I give them a moment on this step, usually just long enough to throw a ball down the hall for my cat a couple times. Then all the pros pour water slowly, in spirals. I base whether my spirals are starting from the outside or the inside on where the most coffee is piled up at this point, thinking about herding it away from where it is, towards where it isn't, either outside or center. I usually use 1.5 scoops of coffee (from the scoop included with the cone) for a 16 oz mug, and it fills up in about two slow pours to about 3/4 inch from the top of the cone. There are more advanced techniques out there, if you care to learn them, but, without too much stress over the details, I get in a little morning meditation on the life of coffee beans (bonus meditation if you add milk and watch it slowly swirl around), a really good cup of coffee, and my cat shows up whenever I start the electric kettle, so it's sort of fun for the whole family.

Cleanup couldn't be easier. Give the filter full of grounds a little squeeze against the side of the cone, throw it out, rinse the cone, and it's ready for the next day.

title: Clearing up a few misconceptions
body:
This brewer is amazing, it's one of the 2 industry standards. There's a lot of misconceptions in reviews of this brewer regarding "how it makes coffee" that I want to help clear up if I can.

This brewer doesn't make coffee, you do!

So the coffee you put in and how you pour the water over it determines how good of coffee comes out the other end but this brewer does have differences from other brewers that allow you to make coffee differently, let me point some of those out.
- Most notably the V60 has a large hole in the bottom so what that means is that when you pour the water over the ground coffee, the brewer provides no resistance slowing down the brew, meaning that if your brew is taking too short or too long, you need to change the coarseness or fineness of you coffee's grind. Do you buy pre-ground coffee? Then maybe you should take a look at the other industry standard, the Kalita Wave, a flat bottom dripper that has 3 tiny holes in the bottom that slow your brew, so you won't have to worry about having a perfect grind.g ribs on the V60 allows there to be some space between the paper filter and the brewer which keeps the brewer from suctioning to your cup or serving glass.
- There are other knock off's of this brewer (like the bialetti) that are much cheaper and may preform similarly, this one is just manufactured better and with a lot more care in the way that it handles your brew. Is the extra price worth it? That's for you to decide, as for me I prefer to have the real thing, the same thing that everyone else uses and that I know assists me best in making a good cup of coffee.

To sum it all up, I would recommend this brewer to anyone interested in making better coffee who's willing to put in some more effort (and money) to do so. If that's what you want to do then I'd definitely recommend looking at some pour over guides on youtube, my favorites are from James Hoffmann and Chris Baca.
If you don't really want to waste extra effort or money trying to make the best cup you can, I'd recommend going with something a little less complex like the kalita wave.

That's my 2 cents, have a great day :)

title: Material of this dripper(not so good, see update at the bottom)
body:
This is a review for the clear plastic version of V60.
Nobody mentioned in the review regarding the material, so here's the information I gathered may help you understand.
It looks acrylic and it is a type of acrylic but Acrylic resin is not a name for certain resin but a family of resin. [...]
On its Hario package says it's "AS resin", it's also known as ASA resin used frequently on automobile and boat exterior parts, which has high degree of weather resistance, understandably. Think of all lamp covers except head lights(made of polycarbonate), brake lamp, parking lamp etc.
It's definitely not the same material you can get at the Costco as a set of acrylic drinkwear which get cracks all over in no time.
If the material can stay under 100 degree Fahrenheit temp day after day for 10 years without developing cracks, you can be sure it'll keep the new look for a long time in the kitchen no matter how hot the water gets through it.

[...]
13) ASA (acrylonitrile styrene acrylate)
Similar to ABS, ASA has great toughness and rigidity, good chemical resistance and thermal stability, outstanding resistance to weather, aging and yellowing, and high gloss. Be careful not to burn this material. It will cause a toxic smoke.
Application: housings, profiles, interior parts and outdoor applications.

Which probably means you have a lifetime investment on it.
Just don't use any abrasives on it and don't burn it.
I had it for a couple of months with daily use and found it's very easy to keep it clean, rinse it, wipe it and the residue left by the water comes off easily(steam from your breath helps, same as glass).

I chose the plastic for the price but now I'm glad I got this over all other materials.
You pay little but you are not getting cheap stuff.

*update*(9-16-16)
Dripper started to developing cracks at near the bottom. I started using it since 9-4-15, it took only little over one year before start seeing the cracks. It's been used daily and a few times each day.
It still works and functionally no issue with it. I'll be using it till it comes part and then going back to trusty dripper made of Polypropylene (made in Holland) which I had used over ten years(possibly close to twenty years).
Hario should consider using different kind of plastic.
I haven't decide if I buy another Hario in different material. Not another plastic Hario for sure.

I'll down rate it to three stars.

I saw some reviewers pointing out that the big single hole at the bottom makes the dripper letting the water go down too fast resulting in brewing weaker coffee. I strongly disagree with that assessment. I use both multiple small hole dripper and this one but I don't see any difference in the strength of the coffee. I even feel that this Hario makes stronger coffee from the same amount of coffee than another one but not by much.
Either of them brew stronger coffee than automatic coffee maker(which I no longer use) for sure. So I use less coffee per cup than I did with the coffee maker.
I also found some people point out that big hole makes the paper filter more likely to break. I normally don't use paper filter (I use home made cloth filter salvaged from my old worn out slacks) but from my experience based on the free paper came with the Hario dripper was different. They held up good.
For anybody interested in making your own clothe filter(which will save many trees), cut a fabric in 5inch by 10inch then hem the three sides(two short and one long edge) and sew the remaining long edge together after fold it in half. I used sewing machine but it can be done by hand sewing too.
Now you have a lifetime supply of filter.
I think 100% polyester is the ideal material but you can experiment with different materials. Some materials let the water go through quicker than the others.

title: Remarkably cheap, remarkably good coffee. Experiment often!
body:
I went from Chemex to the Hario V60 after having numerous baristas recommend it as the "leader" in terms of pour overs. Don't let the unassuming 3 minute brew time hold you back â€” the Hario produces remarkably loud tasting cups. African origins especially (Ethiopian, Kenyan, Burundi) come out with a smooth, syrupy, light body, while tasting notes are very noticeable, even if you are new to "craft coffee". Also, even as a newbie, I occasionally get those amazing aromatics from my coffees.

Things to know about the Hario ecosystem:
- Unlike Chemex and Kalita Wave, the Hario V60 ecosystem is much more sensitive to user input. TL;DR: it requires more tinkering and adjusting variables. This is also why I love it! Take notes of all your variables, note the brew time (aiming for 2:50-3 minutes and absolutely no more than 3:30 or it literally kills the notes), and note the flavors you taste. Repeat repeat repeat. For starters, try 340 grams of water (12oz) and 22 grams of coffee beans. Boil twice the water you need and use the first half to pre-rinse your filter/setup.
- There are so. many. Hario filters. Also unlike Chemex and Kalita Wave, they are not all the same. I get crazy different brew times from the 100pk tabbed vs. the 40pk untabbed. Get the latter. Don't be tempted by the former being cheaper. For the sake of those 18-24$ coffee beans you bought from the fancy coffee shop, buy only the 40pk filters.

title: It works, but you can't use a gold coffee filter with it. It's round and tapers down quickly so...
body:
... when you try to insert a gold filter, there is not enough space inside to enable the filter to set into place. I tried all sorts of gerry-rigging, but nothing worked. They want you to buy their special paper filters but I have no interest in that ecologically or just entrapped in recurring costs.

I used the standard white ceramic pour over dripper for many years. It is shaped inside like the gold-mesh filters, so all was well for many years. Then it fell off counter and broke, and I wasn't up for paying for a brand new one. It wasn't clear to me when reading all the specs of this product and viewing images that my gold filter wouldn't work with this plastic one. I ended up buying a competitor's aluminum dripper with built-in extra-fine filter. So so much easier and the taste is superb. If you like using paper filters however, then this is a very fine pour over coffee dripper for you!

title: Recommend over melitta-style drippers
body:
PROS: Lightweight (I have the clear plastic version), easy to clean. You can see the level of the grounds bed and what's happening.

CONS: Takes some technique with a gooseneck kettle (maybe even one with a flow restrictor...) to get the best taste. Lip doesn't fit inside zojirushi and placing that travel thermos's opening inside this lip causes a vacuum where coffee won't filter. Not sure those spiral raised parts are doing anything in particular to keep airflow/steam moving.

I've made some fantastic cups using this. I use about 40g coffee and about 550ml water -- which makes about 17 ounces of finished coffee. You could probably make a bit more or a bit less, if you wanted to. I don't have a Kalita wave, but I can compare this to a melitta #2-style dripper. It might be slightly easier to get melitta filters in the average grocery store, but I prefer the flavor from the v60 filters. It's surprisingly easy to keep the grounds at 200 degrees (I have a plastic version), if that kind of thing is important to you. You can also use chemex filters in this device if you want to try those filters before buying an entire chemex.

title: V60 is the best for brewing coffee and beginners into pour over
body:
Obviously, the V60 is blowing up right now. Coffee is heading more towards a slower and more methodical way of brewing. The Hario V60 pour over method is arguably the best place to start if you are wanting to get into pour over coffee.

You will need to buy cone filters, I recommend the Hario brand V60 filters (ASIN B001O0R46I) as they fit the best and are high quality. You may also want to consider getting the Hario Gooseneck Kettle (ASIN B000IGOXLS). With these items, along with the cone you are set and well on your way to a full pour over set.

Those looking for a quick cup of coffee to program the night before should stray from this product. I have to budget an extra 10 minutes every morning to brew my pour over right. For me, it's worthy it, as a coffee on the V60 is better than any drip coffee. This is a great product that works well. I bought the plastic one because I was afraid the ceramic would break certainly, turns out the plastic one does too, so don't drop it! Love Hario and the V60.

title: Drip to My Lou
body:
If you want a great dripper, get this. If you want a bad dripper, get something else.

My favorite part is that all of the packaging is not in English. I couldn't read anything and didn't know how to use it.

I wasn't sure if I was supposed to wear it on my head or use it as a funnel. I ended up using it as a multipurpose funnel. I changed the oil on my hog and made a cup of coffee and emptied my cat's litter box.

Not sure I would recommend that to everyone, but I enjoyed all the flavors.

The only CON is that it is clear. Would have been much cooler in a Seafoam Green or Chartreuse.

title: I'm an AeroPress convert.
body: Let me start off by saying I like strong coffee. I prefer bold, heavy-bodied, dark roasted coffee. When I started brewing my own coffee, I started with a regular drip machine, then went to french press, and then AeroPress afterwards. The french press with its immersion brewing created a much stronger cup compared to my regular drip maker but I wasn't a fan of the fines that often made the coffee bitter. When I went to the AeroPress, I got the best of both worlds. I was able to do immersion brewing and then filter out all the fines through a paper filter. I was the biggest fan and advocate of AeroPress for quite some time. I never looked into pour over because I felt that without immersion, I would never produce a cup to my taste. Fast forward a couple years and I started to realize that AeroPress didn't work well with all beans. Some were over-extracted even with lower temps/shorter immersion time. I just couldn't get it right with certain beans and finally decided to try pour over. To my surprise, pour over brewing works exceptionally well and can produce a very clean, strong cup, no matter what beans I use. However, I do find that I use up more coffee per cup than I did with AeroPress. I also found clean up even easier than the AeroPress so I never looked back.

title: Great Coffeemaker and Fun to Use
body: I hesitated for a while because I thought it might be difficult to get good results vs other pour over brewers or the Clever Dripper I've been using and enjoying. But I have had success right from my very first attempts with the V60, and now I understand why it is considered as the quintessential pour over brewer. Impossible to beat the value in the plastic version, it could not be easier to clean, and the coffee is sensational. Plus, it is flat out fun to make coffee with. I guess if I have to find a nit to pick, it would be the filters are designed specifically for this device, so it's another thing to buy. But it really isn't that big of a deal, as they're not outrageously expensive or anything.

title: My Technivorm is now lonely...
body: So glad I purchased this over some of the other pour over drippers. I've paired it with the Hario 1.0l (made in Japan) kettle and am getting marvelous results with my popcorn-popper roasted homeroast coffee. I am also really enjoying the process involved in making a morning pour-over; it just feels nice and adds value to the morning cup. Sadly, my Technivorm Moccamaster has sat mostly idle, lonely and cold save for making coffee on weekends for the kids or to linger over a pot myself. Dont hesitate: just buy this dripper and a nice kettle and enjoy the process/result of home pour overs. Lastly, check out James Hoffman's V60 method on YouTube for one idea on how to make a good pour over. ~NV

body: We have the same one at my job; I HAD to have one for my days off as well! I'm a huge fan of ceramic or glass fixtures and cups over plastic, but this one does not leave a taste, stain, or scratch up during cleaning.
